comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
So your photo there with the wooden fence,   you are claiming is wooloomooloo ?
Can't be,  it wasnt full of farms like that.   And the steep hill with the road and the big pile of sand, where is that supposed to be ?

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content:
I am quite convinced that your third shot there with the wooden fence is not Wooloomooloo and Darlinghurst at all.    It is a shot of Paddington taken from the vicinity of New South Head Road and New Beach Road, looking south.   Paddington Town Hall is on the top of the hill.   The conspicuous street running up the hill is Cascade Street.
The second photo is definitely taken looking WSW from Potts Point and definitely not Paddington.

So if the houses in the background of the first and third photos are indeed the same,    then the first photo must be taken somewhere in the SW corner of Darling Point,  also looking south towards Paddington.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: In the fourth photo,   the two houses in the background in the middle   can be clearly seen as the two houses on either side of Cambridge Street Paddington,   at the junction of Glenmore Road at the foot of Cambridge Street,  in Google Street View.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: There are two more photos in the collection of the Mitchell Library, reproduced in Max Kelly's book Paddock Full of Houses, that show Chinese market gardeners close-up, with the same recognisable buildings in the background. Kelly writes that "this area verging on Rushcutters Bay where the Chinese lived and worked was ... a no-man's land lying outside of care by either the Paddington or the City councils. Low-lying, stinking and abandoned". See: Max Kelly, Paddock Full of Houses: Paddington 1840-1890 (Paddington: Doak Press, 1978), pp. 181-184. 'J. P. M," takes advantage of the presence in the city of epidemic diseases of a virulent character to bring under the notice of the City, Paddington, and Woollahra municipal councils one of the most dangerous sources of zymotic diseases in our midst, namely, the Valley of Lacrozia (or Chinaman's Garden), at Rushcutter Bay. The spot, he says, is a very hotbed of disease germs. Throughout the winter a heavy nauseating vapour defines the locality, and during the summer months the exhalations are poisonous. The sewage from Woollahra on the one side, and Darlinghurst, in the vicinity of St. Vincent's Hospital, on the other, empties into the spot, the abominations of which are self-assertive. - The Sydney Morning Herald, Wednesday 3 September 1884, p. 9. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13573328 Anti-Chinese feelings grew in intensity during the 1880s, and numerous public meetings were held in Paddington to protest against the disease risk the Chinese Gardens presented (for example: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13419512 and trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13632263). Some did more than attend meetings and sign petitions - to ruin the gardens was said to be a favourite Sunday pastime. At least one local was appalled and wrote to the Sydney Morning Herald in 1879: THE CHINESE AGAIN - TO THE EDITOR OF THE HERALD. Sir, - I wish to call the attention of the police authorities to what appears to be a systematic persecution, by a number of larrikins. on a few poor Chinese who have a market garden situated between Rushcutter Bay and the Glenmore Road, and of part of which persecution I was an eyewitness, last Saturday afternoon. These noble-souled youths came down in a body upon these poor gardeners (one of whom is just recovering from a severe illness) with yells and whoops, and the foulest of foul language, hurling stones upon the roof of their dwelling, and at the men who were enraged and driven to desperation, not knowing what to do or where to turn to get redress, seeming too very fearful of making any complaint, and rather inclined to put up with a great deal of annoyance (to no little of which they have been subjected at different times, such as the cutting up of their melon vines in the night, and similar kindly actions) rather than come into unfriendly collision with us Europeans. They informed me that the attack upon them on the previous Saturday lasted a full hour, from 3 to 4 o'clock. It only requires I know, that this state of affairs should be made public to ensure the complete safety of these men; for though many of our most honourable do not approve of inundating this land with Chinese, yet there are few worth callîng men who would refuse to protect those who have formed an asylum among us, and who are certainly "The strangers that are within our gates." To take the very lowest ground of all, and call them animals, then they must be protected, for we have a Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. I think it only fair to state, that these larrikins were not residents of the neighbourhood, but were en route from some unknown point of interest to another. August 16. Spectator - The Sydney Morning Herald, Tuesday 19 August 1879, p. 6. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13445709 Eventually the area was resumed - sometime in the 1890s? - (the proposal was tabled in NSW Parliament in 1891 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13859586), and I think the photos were taken as part of the resumption process, just as photos were taken prior to the Blackwattle, Darling Harbour, and Rocks resumptions.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Great work, well done!  What a sad, forgotten chapter in NSW history.  

The market gardens rang a bell - another view of the house on the left -

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: In mid-1908 Sydney promoter Hugh Donald Macintosh (he acted as the referee in the boxing match pictured below) leased part of this area to promote major boxing matches. It is said he paid next to nothing for the initial lease, and made a fortune. The Sydney Stadium was demolished in 1973 to make way for the railway. - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sydney_Stadium Burns-Johnson boxing contest, December 26th 1908 by Charles Kerry [SLNSW: a128719] Here's a bird's eye view of the area in 1968 - Aerial view of Sydney Stadium at Rushcutters Bay, 1968, the stadium situated bottom middle, circular building by Ern McQuillan [NLA: nla.pic-vn3562173] And here's a view of the area today taken from the Bondi Junction train line - www.panoramio.com/photo/16962161 Déjà vu? - Market gardens 'not safe', SMH, March 2, 2011 www.smh.com.au/nsw/market-gardens-not-safe-20110301-1bd8e...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Golly, there's enough for a thesis there! Also the area to the east of the stadium and in this photo became the original White City Amusement Park for a relatively short time from 1913 - (beware postcard collection ahead) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.pic-vn3119936 . Something I never knew about before. I think this whole area is the key to a lot of the "untitled" photos in Series 4481. For example, I bet this shack is along the ridge behind the house - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4753617030/]
